questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UPT

 

Explanation:

 

In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.

 

Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.

 

Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

choices.text: A case of superfetation
One infant is atavistic
A case of superfecundation
One infant is suppositious

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation:

 

  • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.

 

Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.

 

Option D. One infant is suppositious: Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

 

Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the labor room at 38 weeks. At 1 pm she is 5 cm dilated. After 4 hours she is 6 cm dilated. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ARM + oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is experiencing protracted labor, as indicated by a slow progression in cervical dilation (only 1 cm increase in 4 hours). In active labor, the cervix is expected to dilate at a rate of approximately 1 cm per hour. Here, the cervix dilated from 5 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours, indicating a slow or protracted dilation phase.

 

Management of Protracted Labor:

 

Assessment: Evaluate the cause of slow labor, which could be due to issues with powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).

 

Augmentation of Labor:

 

  • 1st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress.
  • 2nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine: This is not recommended as it allows prolonged labor to continue without intervention, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While a cesarean section may be necessary if augmentation fails or if there are other indications, it is not the immediate next step without attempting augmentation.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm), not at 6 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a primigravida with protracted labor (slow cervical dilation), the next best step is to perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and administer oxytocin to augment labor and promote adequate uterine contractions.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism in men is seen with deficiency of? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace mineral that plays a crucial role in various biological functions, including immune response, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. It is also vital for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, as well as for proper reproductive function.

 

Zinc Deficiency and Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in men can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism. Hypogonadism refers to reduced function of the gonads (testes in men), which can lead to lower testosterone levels and may result in symptoms such as decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and reduced secondary sexual characteristics. Zinc is important for the synthesis of testosterone and its deficiency can impair reproductive health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is essential for male reproductive health, and its deficiency can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hair growth

 

  • Hair growth (Pubarche): The development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.
  • Estrogen effects: Estrogen plays a crucial role in various aspects of puberty, including:
    • Breast development (thelarche)
    • Development of internal genitalia
    • Menarche
    • Regulation of growth spurt
    • Epiphyseal closure
    • Cervical mucus plug formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus.

 

Option C. Vaginal cornification: Estrogen promotes the cornification (maturation) of the vaginal epithelium.

 

Option D. Menstruation: Estrogen is critical in regulating the menstrual cycle and the onset of menarche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.

 

Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings:  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. 
  • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

 

Educational Objective:

 

To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:

 

  • Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency.
  • Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring.
  • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins.
  • Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg 380,

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is a significant rise in progesterone levels, which is crucial for the transformation of the endometrium into a secretory phase. This phase is essential for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation of an embryo.

 

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:

 

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days):
    • The shedding of the endometrial lining occurs if there is no pregnancy.
  2. Follicular Phase (10 - 14 days):
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
    • Estrogen levels rise, leading to the proliferation of the endometrium.
  3. Ovulation (14th day):
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH) surge leads to the release of an ovum from the dominant follicle.
  4. Luteal Phase (14 - 28 days):
    • The corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone.
    • Progesterone causes the endometrium to develop secretory glands and prepare for implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone: LH is primarily involved in triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum.

 

Option B. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone: FSH is crucial for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Estrogen is significant during the follicular phase for the proliferation of the endometrium but is not the main hormone acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the hormone responsible for preparing the endometrium for implantation during the post-ovulatory phase.

 

Ref: Page no 94, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial polyp

 

  • The image is an ultrasound image of the uterus with a thickened endometrium.
  • The presence of a feeding vessel is very suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibroid uterus: Fibroid uterus would generally show a different pattern on ultrasound and is characterized by increased vascularity, but it wouldn't typically present with a single feeding vessel like an endometrial polyp.

 

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: In endometrial carcinoma, the endometrium would be irregularly thickened with loss of endo-myometrial junction and cystic spaces with increased vascularity throughout.

 

Option D. Leiomyosarcoma: Leiomyosarcoma, similar to fibroids, would show increased vascularity but with more aggressive features and not a solitary feeding vessel as seen in polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a single feeding vessel in a mass seen on ultrasonography is highly suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Ref: Page no 460, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option C. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option D. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is done for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months

 

Explanation:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of a baby's life. During this period, the infant receives only breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water. Breast milk provides all the essential nutrients, antibodies, and hydration needed for optimal growth and development during these first crucial months. The World Health Organization (WHO) and other health authorities strongly advocate for exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months due to its significant health benefits for both the baby and the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding should be practiced for the first 6 months of a baby's life to ensure they receive optimal nutrition and immune support.

questions.text: Which menstrual cycle length is abnormal? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) >38 days

 

Explanation:

 

According to the latest FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification, the normal menstrual cycle length ranges from 24 to 38 days. A cycle length exceeding 38 days is considered abnormal and is classified as infrequent or delayed menstruation. Previously, the normal range was considered 21 to 35 days, but this has been updated to reflect a broader range of normal cycle lengths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menstrual cycle abnormalities are categorized based on the frequency of the cycles:

 

  • Frequent cycles: Less than 24 days
  • Normal cycles: 24 to 38 days
  • Infrequent cycles: More than 38 days

 

Understanding these classifications helps in diagnosing and managing menstrual disorders effectively.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. If it results in 2 living children, it will be Live 2.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G2P2: Incorrect because the woman has had only one previous pregnancy that reached viability, not two.

 

Option B. G3P2: Incorrect because this implies she has had three pregnancies and two have reached viability, which is not the case.

 

Option D. G3P1: Incorrect because this implies three pregnancies, but she is currently in her second pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A twin pregnancy that has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1, not Para 2. If it results in two living children, it will be Live 2.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

 

Explanation:

 

The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:

 

  • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.

 

Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:

 

  • ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation

 

Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: What is given to prevent neural tube defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid supplementation is essential for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are severe birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, that occur when the neural tube does not close completely. Folic acid, a B-vitamin, significantly reduces the risk of these defects when taken in adequate amounts before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

It is recommended that women start taking folic acid atleast three months before conception and continue through the first three months of pregnancy.

 

For women at low risk, the recommended dose is 0.4 to 0.5 mg per day.

 

For those at high risk, including women with a previous pregnancy affected by NTDs, known folate deficiency, overt diabetes mellitus, or those on anti-epileptic drugs, the recommended dose is 4 to 5 mg per day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: This option is incorrect as iron supplementation is used primarily to prevent and treat anemia in pregnancy, not to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option B. Calcium: This is incorrect because calcium is important for the development of the fetal skeletal system and for maternal bone health, but it does not prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: This option is incorrect as vitamin B12, while important for overall neurological health, is not the primary supplement used to prevent neural tube defects. However, B12 works synergistically with folic acid, and deficiency in B12 can contribute to NTDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy is crucial to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

choices.text: Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception
Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets

questions.text: Reema Devi, A 28y newly married woman presents to your sub center for contraceptive advice. She is started on Oral Contraceptive Pills. She presents after 2 weeks with a history of missing 4 tablets on different days in the first 2 weeks of the cycle. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h

 

 

Missing a pill increases the risk of pregnancy.

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

** In this question, she has missed 4 pills in the 1st 2 weeks Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception, use emergency contraception, and continue the remaining pack

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception: Discontinuing the packet is not advised as it can lead to hormonal imbalance and irregular cycles. An alternate method of contraception can be considered only if the patient prefers to switch, but it is not an immediate solution for the current cycle's missed pills.

 

Option B. Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give emergency pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 hours: Taking 4 tablets the next day is excessive and unnecessary. The correct approach is to take the last missed pill and continue as usual.

 

Option D. Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets: This option neglects the need for additional contraception and emergency contraception, which are crucial to prevent pregnancy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman misses multiple oral contraceptive pills, she should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception, and consider emergency contraception if she had intercourse in the last 72 hours.

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) includes endometritis, salpingitis, oophoritis, and parametritis. Any interventions like dilatation and curettage (D&C) are contraindicated in active PID due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing further complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: D&C is not contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy; however, it is not typically performed in its management as it does not provide any benefit for this condition.

 

Option C. Menstrual irregularities: D&C can be performed to obtain an endometrial biopsy in peri-menopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) if there are no other identifiable causes and if endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy is suspected.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: D&C is not usually performed solely for endometriosis unless there is an associated AUB that needs to be evaluated or treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of spreading the infection

 

Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

choices.text: Prolonged second stage

questions.text: Which of the following situations is not managed by using Ventouse for a delivery? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premature baby

 

Explanation:

 

Ventouse assisted delivery can cause Intracranial hemorrhage in a preterm fetus

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged second stage: Ventouse is commonly indicated for prolonged second stage of labor to assist in the delivery process.

 

Option B. Maternal Exhaustion: Maternal exhaustion is another indication for operative vaginal delivery using either forceps or ventouse to expedite delivery and reduce maternal strain.

 

Option C. Fetal Distress: Fetal distress is an indication for immediate delivery, and ventouse can be used to quickly assist in the delivery when immediate intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventouse-assisted delivery is contraindicated in premature babies due to the risk of intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Ref: D.C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 652,661

choices.text: Mullerian agenesis
Gonadal dysgenesis
Turner syndrome
Testicular feminization syndrome

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mullerian agenesis

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.
  • Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • As ovaries are present, normal secondary sexual characters will develop

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis patients present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters poorly developed breasts

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters and short stature will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. The ovaries are streak ovaries

 

Option D. Testicular feminization syndrome: Testicular feminization syndrome also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46XY. Secondary sexual characters like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

 

Educational Objective:


Mullerian agenesis is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, with normal ovarian function leading to normal breast and pubic hair development.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colposcopy directed biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A positive pap smear indicates the presence of some cytological abnormality (such as epithelial or glandular cell abnormalities). The next appropriate step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy. Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix, allowing for the identification and biopsy of abnormal areas. During the colposcopy, scoring systems like Ried’s index or Swede’s score are used to evaluate the severity of the pathology, and cervical biopsy samples are taken from acetowhite areas identified during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):

 

  • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is:
    • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized).
    • Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy.
    • Positive endocervical curettage.
    • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.

 

Option C. Repeat pap smear:

 

  • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy:

 

  • Hysterectomy is never indicated solely for an abnormal pap smear. It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows:
    • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis.
    • Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment.
    • High-grade CIN in elderly women.
    • Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following a positive pap smear indicating abnormal cytology, the next step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy to further evaluate and manage the cervical pathology.

 

Ref: Page no 329, Dc Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Repeat Colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as HSIL. On colposcopy and biopsy, it was confirmed to be carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conization

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:

 

  • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.

 

Option C. Repeat colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months: In the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred. There is no need of repeat colpobiopsy 

 

Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.

 

 

Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 69 XXY

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are characterized by being triploid, meaning they have three sets of chromosomes. The chromosome number for a partial mole is typically 69, which can be either 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

  • Formation of Partial Mole:
    • Partial moles occur when two sperm fertilize a single ovum (egg). This process is called diandry.
    • As a result, both maternal and paternal genetic components are present in a partial mole.
    • The most common karyotypes for partial moles are 69XXX and 69XXY.
  • Complete Mole Characteristics:
    • Complete moles are diploid, meaning they have two sets of chromosomes.
    • They form either by:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum and then undergoing duplication, a process known as androgenesis, or
      • Two sperm (dispermy) fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum.
    • The chromosome number for complete moles is typically 46XX or 46XY.
    • Only the paternal genetic component is present, with no maternal contribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: This karyotype is typical for a complete mole, not a partial mole.

 

Option B. 45 XY: This karyotype is not typical for either complete or partial moles.

 

Option C. 69 XY: This option is incorrect as partial moles can be 69XY, but 69XXY is more specific and typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are triploid, typically having a chromosome number of 69, which can be 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

Ref: Page no 616, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Stria Gravidarum
Linea Alba
Linea Nigra
Stria albicans

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linea Nigra

 

Explanation:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stria gravidarum: Stria gravidarum is a reddish stria of present pregnancy.

 

Option B. Linea Alba: The midline of the anterior abdominal wall skin. It takes on dark brown-black pigmentation to form the linea nigra.

 

 Option D. Stria albicans: Stria albicans is a silvery stria of previous pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Ref: Page no 79, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Review USG after 2 weeks
Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
ECV at 36 weeks
Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
    • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
    • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
    • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.

 

Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

 

Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle
Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle
Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles
It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the Sertoli cells in males and the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in females. It serves as a marker of ovarian reserve and is crucial in assessing fertility potential. Here are the reasons why option A is incorrect:

 

  • AMH Testing: Unlike some other hormones, AMH does not require fasting and can be tested at any time during the menstrual cycle. The timing of testing AMH is not restricted to day 2 of the menstrual cycle as with some other reproductive hormone assessments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle: This is a true statement. AMH is indeed a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in the ovaries.

 

Option C. Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles: This is also true. AMH levels correlate with ovarian reserve and can give an indication of the likelihood of a successful IVF cycle. Higher levels generally suggest a better response to ovarian stimulation and thus potentially higher pregnancy rates.

 

Option D. It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH: This statement is correct. AMH reduces the sensitivity of pre-antral and small antral follicles to Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which is a mechanism to regulate follicle recruitment and maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: At the onset of labor
40 weeks

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with cardiac disease involves switching from warfarin to heparin at specific times to minimize the risk of complications to the fetus and to prepare for delivery.

 

  • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

 

Guidelines Summary:

 

  1. Early Pregnancy (up to 12 weeks):
    • Discontinue warfarin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed, especially if the warfarin dose is >5mg/day, due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy.
    • Replace with heparin (5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).
  2. After 12 Weeks to 36 Weeks:
    • Warfarin can be resumed after the 12th week and continued up to 36 weeks.
  3. At 36 Weeks:
    • Switch from warfarin to heparin (either unfractionated or LMWH).
  4. Just Before Delivery:
    • Discontinue heparin just before delivery.
  5. Postpartum:
    • Restart heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
    • Warfarin therapy can also be safely resumed during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The final switch from warfarin to heparin in pregnant women with cardiac disease is advised at 36 weeks of gestation to minimize the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

 

Explanation:

 

The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:

 

  • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy: COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.

 

However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.

 

Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 489

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 37 weeks. She is a known case of heart disease with a prosthetic valve on warfarin. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to LMWH

 

The patient is a 37-week pregnant woman with a known case of heart disease and a prosthetic valve, currently on warfarin. In pregnant patients with prosthetic heart valves, anticoagulation management is crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications. Warfarin is typically avoided in the late third trimester due to the risk of fetal bleeding and other complications during delivery. It is recommended to switch from warfarin to heparin (usually low molecular weight heparin, LMWH) at around 36 weeks of gestation.

 

Since the patient is still on warfarin at 37 weeks, the immediate action is to switch to LMWH to reduce the risks associated with warfarin during labor and delivery. Before planning an induction of labor (IOL) or cesarean section, heparin should be stopped 12-24 hours before the planned delivery to minimize the risk of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin at this stage is inappropriate because it increases the risk of bleeding for both the mother and the fetus during labor or delivery. Warfarin crosses the placenta and poses significant risks during the peripartum period.

 

Option C. Immediate cesarean: There is no immediate indication for a cesarean section based on her anticoagulation status alone. Cesarean delivery would only be indicated for obstetric reasons. Moreover, performing surgery while the patient is on warfarin increases the risk of severe bleeding complications.

 

Option D. Immediate IOL (Induction of Labor): Immediate induction of labor is not the first step as the patient is still on warfarin, which poses a bleeding risk. Before planning any delivery method, it is essential to switch to heparin and allow a safe window without anticoagulation before proceeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves on warfarin, switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at 36 weeks to reduce the risk of complications during delivery, and stop heparin 12-24 hours before planned delivery.

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  2. Anti-androgens
  3. Lifestyle modifications
  4. Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation of irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair, combined with increased ovarian volume, is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The first-line treatment options for PCOS typically include:

 

Anti-androgens (2): These medications help reduce symptoms related to excess androgens, such as facial hair and acne. Common examples include spironolactone.

 

Lifestyle modifications (3): These are crucial for managing PCOS. Weight loss and exercise can improve insulin sensitivity and help regulate menstrual cycles.

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (4): These are used to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce hyperandrogenism symptoms (like hirsutism), and provide endometrial protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1): This is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS, but it is generally considered a second-line treatment. It is typically performed when medical management fails to achieve the desired results.

 

Educational Objective:


The first-line treatments for PCOS include anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptive pills.

 

Ref: Page no 460, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text:
The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Lactogenesis
  2. Mammogenesis
  3. Galactopoiesis
  4. Galactokinesis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The process of lactation involves several stages, each with specific physiological changes. Understanding these stages helps in comprehending the sequence of events that occur from the preparation of the breast during pregnancy to the maintenance of milk production.

 

2. Mammogenesis: This is the first stage, involving the development and growth of the mammary glands in preparation for lactation. It occurs during pregnancy when the breast tissue proliferates and differentiates under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.

 

1. Lactogenesis: This stage refers to the initiation of milk production, which begins around the time of birth. Lactogenesis is divided into two phases:
 

  • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk.
  • Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.

 

4. Galactokinesis: This stage involves the ejection or movement of milk from the alveoli to the nipple. It is facilitated by the let-down reflex, which is triggered by the hormone oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the myoepithelial cells around the alveoli to contract, expelling the milk into the ducts and out through the nipple.

 

3. Galactopoiesis: This final stage refers to the maintenance of milk production. It is sustained by the regular removal of milk from the breast, either through breastfeeding or pumping, which maintains prolactin levels and keeps the milk supply ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in lactation during the puerperium is: Mammogenesis (breast development), Lactogenesis (initiation of milk production), Galactokinesis (milk ejection), and Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production).

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

The treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially caused by Plasmodium vivax, requires special consideration due to the potential effects on both the mother and the fetus. The key points are:

 

  • Chloroquine: Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women. It is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Alternative Drugs: If there is resistance to chloroquine, quinine can be used as a secondary option.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum malaria, artesunate is the preferred drug, followed by quinine, both of which can be safely used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: This combination is not used in pregnancy due to the contraindication of primaquine. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially in those with G6PD deficiency. It is not used for radical cure in pregnant women and is deferred until after delivery.

 

Option C. Quinine: While quinine can be used if there is resistance to chloroquine, it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax.

 

Option D. Artesunate: Artesunate is the drug of choice for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but not for Plasmodium vivax in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

 

  • Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

Maternal deaths can be classified into direct and indirect causes. Direct causes are those that result from complications of pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period, whereas indirect causes are conditions that are exacerbated by pregnancy.

 

Pre-eclampsia: This is a direct cause of maternal death. Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke, and organ failure, all of which can directly result in maternal mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: This is considered an indirect cause of maternal death. While severe anemia can exacerbate complications during pregnancy and childbirth, it is not a direct cause but increases the risk of infections, hemorrhage, and other complications.

 

Option B. Heart disease: This is also an indirect cause of maternal death. Pre-existing heart disease can worsen during pregnancy due to the increased cardiovascular demands, but it is not a complication arising directly from pregnancy.

 

Option C. Embolism: Pulmonary embolism is considered an indirect cause of maternal death when it occurs due to pregnancy-related factors like deep vein thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, directly associated with complications arising from pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period.

choices.text: Dichorionic Diamniotic
Dichorionic Monoamniotic
Monochorionic Monoamniotic
Conjoined twins

questions.text: Which of the following can be expected if division of zygote occurs between 8 – 12 days after fertilization? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic Monoamniotic

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dichorionic Diamniotic: Occurs when the division of the zygote happens within the first 3 days after fertilization.

 

Option B. Dichorionic Monoamniotic: This is not a typical classification in twin pregnancies.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: Result from the division of the zygote occurring after the 13th day of fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins result from the division of the zygote occurring between 8 to 12 days after fertilization.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 24th edition page 893

choices.text: Continue same diet

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue same diet

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half. During the first trimester, there is no need for additional calories. The caloric increase is recommended as follows:

 

  • 0 Kcal in 1st trimester
  • 340 Kcal in 2nd trimester
  • 452 Kcal in 3rd trimester

 

In this question, extra calories in the 1st trimester are asked, so the answer will be no additional requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Page no 487, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naloxone

 

Explanation:

 

Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

  • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • As per Williams Obstetrics:
    • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
    • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
    • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Additional 300kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.

 

Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.

 

Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

choices.text: Cusco's speculum
﻿﻿﻿Sims' speculum

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cusco's speculum

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is Cusco's speculum.
  • Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualization of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.
  • Advantage: Self retaining
  • Disadvantage: Less space so can’t be used for some procedures, obscures the vaginal walls so vaginal lesion may be missed

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sim Speculum:

 

 

Option C. Proctoscope

 

 

Option D. Doyen Retractor

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualizing the cervix and vaginal fornices.

 

Ref: Page no 628, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) levonorgesterel IUD

 

Explanation:

 

  • Suitable during lactation
    • LNG-IUS is a progestin-only method
    • Does not reduce milk production (unlike estrogen-containing pills)
  • Controls heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • LNG-IUS reduces menstrual blood loss by 70–90%
    • Improves hemoglobin levels and quality of life
  • Long-acting and reversible
    • Provides effective contraception for up to 5 years
    • Fertility returns quickly after removal
  • Low maintenance
    • No daily action required
    • Ideal for busy mothers with young children
  • High efficacy
    • Failure rate <0.2% per year
    • One of the most effective reversible methods
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
    • Category 1 (no restriction) after 6 weeks postpartum
    • Safe for breastfeeding women
  • Fewer systemic side effects
    • Hormone acts locally in the uterus
    • Minimal systemic absorption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Mala N: Mala N is also a possible contraceptive in this situation. There is high chance of non compliance and missed pill. LNG IUS is better option in such cases

 

Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection: Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. it may lead to delay in return to menses, and also requires follow up every 3 months for next dose, which is inconvenient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 357

questions.text:
Which of the following cannot cross the placenta? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  1. Iron
  2. Albumin
  3. Immunoglobulin M
  4. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the placenta.

 

Other Options:
